facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 254 of 1962 is an appeal by special leave from the Award dated May 1, 1961 of the Industrial Tribunal, U.P. at Allahabad in Reference No. 69 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 254 of 1962. Appeal by special leave from the Award dated May 1, 1961, of the Industrial Tribunal  111 , U.P. at Allahabad in Reference No. 69 of 1959.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on August 3, 1962 by MUDHOLKAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962, August 3- The Judgment of the companyrt was delivered by MUDHOLKAR, J.-The only point for companysideration in this appeal by special leave

facts.text: Appellants claim the crushing season of 1958-59 ended on March 16, 1959 when all ancillary operations ended and machinery at standstill.

anchor.surface_text: is whether the crushing season of 1958-59 must be deemed to have ended on March 12, 1959 when the actual crushing of sugar cane stopped or on March 16, 1959 when all ancillary operations in the factory came to an end and the entire machinery was at a standstill. According to the appellants the crushing season

facts.text: Respondents claim the crushing season of 1958-59 ended on March 12, 1959 when actual crushing of sugar cane stopped.

anchor.surface_text: came to an end on the latter date while according to the respondents who are the employees of the factory it came to an end on the former date. The importance of determining the date on which the season terminated arises out of the admitted position that only those seasonal workers

facts.text: Only seasonal workers borne on the muster roll on the day next to the end of crushing season entitled to three days closure holidays.

anchor.surface_text: The importance of determining the date on which the season terminated arises out of the admitted position that only those seasonal workers who are borne on the muster roll of the factory on the day next to the date on which the crushing season ended would be entitled to three days clos- ure holidays. It is the case of the respondents

facts.text: Appellants employ about 1,600 seasonal workers and about 650 permanent workers.

anchor.surface_text: It is the case of the respondents that the appellants employ about 1,600 seasonal workers and about 650 permanent workers. It is companymon ground that the crushing process terminated on March 12, 1959, and on that day about 1,000

facts.text: Crushing process terminated on March 12, 1959 and about 1,000 of 1,600 seasonal workers left for homes by evening after receiving dues.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that the crushing process terminated on March 12, 1959, and on that day about 1,000 of the 1,600 seasonal workers left for their homes by the evening after receiving all their dues. The remaining seasonal workers companytinued to work in the factory till March 16, 1959,

facts.text: Remaining seasonal workers continued to work till March 16, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The remaining seasonal workers companytinued to work in the factory till March 16, 1959, and, therefore, under a term of an award of the Industrial Tribunal in reference No. 33 of 53 and dated April 15, 1953, they are entitled to three days closure holidays. The case of the appellants, however,

facts.text: Award of Industrial Tribunal in Reference No. 33 of 1953 dated April 15, 1953 provides entitlement to closure holidays.

anchor.surface_text: The remaining seasonal workers companytinued to work in the factory till March 16, 1959, and, therefore, under a term of an award of the Industrial Tribunal in reference No. 33 of 53 and dated April 15, 1953, they are entitled to three days closure holidays. The case of the appellants, however,

facts.text: Appellants claim crushing season ended on March 16, 1959, last day factory worked, only workers on roll on March 17 entitled.

anchor.surface_text: is that the crushing season must be regarded as having ended on March 16, 1959 which was the last day on which the factory was worked and that only those seasonal workers who were borne on the muster roll of the factory on March 17, 1959 would be entitled to three days closure holidays. The 600 seasonal workers

facts.text: 600 seasonal workers worked till evening of March 16, 1959 not entitled according to appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The 600 seasonal workers who worked till the evening of March 16, 1959, would therefore, according to them number be entitled to closure holidays. During arguments Mr. Pathak also suggested that the fact that between March 12 and March 16,1959, 600 seasonal workers

facts.text: Evidence of WW1 B.S. Chauhan, member of executive of U.P. Trade Union Congress, Kanpur, shows seasonal workers other than those left March 12 evening were on muster roll on March 13, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Taking up the last point it is sufficient to point out that the evidence of W. W. 1, B. S. Chauhan, who is a member of the executive of the U. P. Trade Union Congress, Kanpur, shows that the seasonal workers other than those who left on the evening of March 12, 1959, were borne on the muster roll of the appellants on March 13, 1959. His evidence

facts.text: Evidence of B.S. Chauhan on muster roll March 13 not challenged in cross-examination.

anchor.surface_text: His evidence on the point has number been challenged in the cross-examination. Nor have the appellants examined any witness for the purpose of showing how many seasonal workers were borne on the muster roll on March 13, 1959.

facts.text: Appellants examined no witness on number of seasonal workers on muster roll on March 13, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Nor have the appellants examined any witness for the purpose of showing how many seasonal workers were borne on the muster roll on March 13, 1959. The only witness examined by them, Shri K. K. Sinha, who is working as Manufacturing Chemist,

facts.text: Appellants' witness Shri K.K. Sinha, Manufacturing Chemist, had no knowledge as he was not working in 1958-59 crushing season.

anchor.surface_text: The only witness examined by them, Shri K. K. Sinha, who is working as Manufacturing Chemist, has numberknowledge about the matter because, as admitted by him in his cross-examination, he was number working in the mills in the 1958-59 crushing season. Since the total number of seasonal workers

facts.text: Total seasonal workers 1,600, nearly 1,000 left March 12, 1959, so number who continued till March 16, 1959 is 600.

anchor.surface_text: Since the total number of seasonal workers was 1,600 and nearly a thousand had left on March 12, 1959 the number of those, who companytinued to work till March 16, 1959 must be six hundred. We must, therefore. proceed on the basis that the names of about 600 seasonal workers

facts.text: About 600 seasonal workers borne on muster roll on March 13, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore. proceed on the basis that the names of about 600 seasonal workers companytinued to be borne on the muster roll of the appellants on March 13, 1959. What has to be companysidered then is what was the date on which the crushing season of 1958-59 ended. It seems to us clear

facts.text: Crushing season ended on date crushing operations ended, March 12, 1959, not when all manufacturing processes ended.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us clear that the crushing season must be deemed to have ended on the date on which the crushing operations in the factory came to an end and number on the date on which the manu- facturing processes in the factory came to an end. We must give to the expression crushing season its ordinary meaning,

facts.text: No evidence before Tribunal that crushing season meant period factory working, not merely crushing operations.

anchor.surface_text: There was numberevidence before the Tribunal to the effect that crushing season meant the period during which the factory was actually working and number merely the period during which the crushing operations were being carried on. facts.text: Clause 3 of 1953 Award: permanent workers and seasonal on roll day following close of crushing season entitled to closure holidays.

facts.text: Nothing in 1953 Award indicates crushing season meant other than period crushing operations carried on.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberhing in the Award to indicate that according to the Tribunal crushing season meant anything else than the period during which Crushing operations were carried on. Since, as already pointed out the operations came to an end on March 12,1959

facts.text: Crushing operations came to end on March 12, 1959, so crushing season ended that day.

anchor.surface_text: Since, as already pointed out the operations came to an end on March 12,1959 the crushing season must be held to have ended on that day.
